subsection_content:
1. Is appendicitis dangerous?
If the inflammation is not treated, the appendix will burst, spreading harmful bacteria into the abdominal cavity, including the central part that contains the liver, stomach, and intestines. This leads to peritonitis, even death. However, the disease can be well controlled with prompt treatment with strong antibiotics and surgery.
2. Caring for patients after appendicitis surgery
Laparoscopic appendectomy usually has a quick recovery time. Patients can be discharged from the hospital after just a few days of treatment, even within 24 hours. With open surgery, the time can last up to a week.
During the first few days after surgery, the patient will feel pain and show signs of bruising. This condition will improve over time, but pain relievers can also be used if necessary. Patients may also experience constipation for a short time after treatment. Helpful care solutions include taking codeine pain relievers, eating lots of fiber and drinking enough water.(6)
Before leaving the hospital, the doctor will advise you in detail about the wound treatment process as well as activities to avoid. Relatives need to pay attention to know how to properly care for them.
3. How long is the incubation period for appendicitis?
For acute appendicitis: This is a case of serious inflammation, often occurring suddenly, most commonly between the ages of 10 and 30, especially in men. The pain tends to get worse within 24 hours.(5)
For chronic appendicitis: Symptoms may be relatively mild, often occurring after an acute case of inflammation. Accordingly, signs of pain tend to disappear before reappearing over a period of weeks, months or even years. This type of appendicitis can be difficult to diagnose, sometimes only being discovered when it develops acutely.
4. Does appendicitis go away on its own?
Appendicitis cannot go away on its own and must be surgically removed as soon as possible to avoid dangerous complications. This method is also often recommended when inflammation cannot be clearly diagnosed.(7)
